supporting.text: Canada has strong legal protections for freedom of expression, including in literature, under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

attacks.text: Canada has strong legal protections for freedom of expression, including in literature, under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Despite legal protections, Canada has banned or restricted books deemed hate speech or obscene under criminal law.
The number of books banned or restricted in Canada is extremely low compared to the total volume of published works.
Certain provinces have removed books from school curricula or libraries due to controversial content, effectively limiting access.
Provincial decisions on school materials do not constitute nationwide bans and often involve public consultation.

supporting.text: The Canadian legal system requires substantial justification to ban books, typically limited to extreme cases like hate speech or obscenity.

attacks.text: The Canadian legal system requires substantial justification to ban books, typically limited to extreme cases like hate speech or obscenity.

supporting.text: Canada does not maintain a comprehensive list of banned books, unlike some countries with stricter censorship laws.

attacks.text: Canada does not maintain a comprehensive list of banned books, unlike some countries with stricter censorship laws.

Historical obscenity laws are no longer actively enforced in Canada, and modern standards of free expression make such bans unlikely today.
